Military members are on my mind tonight. Last night I met with Dr. Robert Taylor, USMC Colonel, retired. Dr. Taylor has a PhD in psychology, and teaches at Richland CC. He was the Director of Safety for the Marine Corps during Desert Storm. He now serves as the Illinois Council President of the Military Officers Association of America. The MOAA advocates for military members, both active and retired. Our military is a volunteer force. Recruitment and retention are significant issues, especially retention. Major retention issues are the "Ops tempo,"  that is, the length and frequency of deployment. Another is the poor quality of life in off-base housing. Finally, family support during deployment needs to improve. Why would families of deployed military need SNAP (food stamp) support? Promises are made at the time of recruitment, but they are not kept with retirement and health care benefits. The pension plan is changing, for better or worse. Health care is a moving target. Benefits need to stabilize if we hope to retain a volunteer military. The final lesson for me, and I hope for you, is that those members who leave military service are NOT damaged. Yes, some have suffered PTSD and other injuries, and need compassion and the best care. But the media perception of drug abuse and homelessness does not apply to the vast majority. Most are well-trained, clean, respectful, hard-working, and punctual. They are of all races. They are our veterans, and they have specific issues, such as the widow's tax that Congress has not dealt with in 15 years! Enough! Thank you Dr. Taylor for a free education on our great volunteer military.members, active and retired. Thank you for being such a good officer to your men and women during your retirement from active military service. I'm sorry that 'thank you for your service" can sound hollow. Help me make it real for our military members.
